dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Conversational and analytical, but consistently misrepresenting the source material.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright folks, welcome back. So, uh, we've been watching the markets, and this week has been, well, pretty wild. The S&P 500, like, really took a hit on Wednesday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright folks, welcome back. So, uh, we've been watching the markets, and this week has been, well, pretty wild. The S and P five hundred, like, really took a hit on Wednesday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the S&P 500 saw its best 50-day streak in its history even as a massive wave of protests in the aftermath of the death of George Floyd continued to unfold across the country...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Host A, it did. And, you know, it's really interesting because a lot of experts are kind of connecting this collapse to the George Floyd protests. And, uh, they're also predicting a pretty robust May unemployment rate, just like they thought.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Host A, it did. And, you know, it's really interesting because a lot of experts are kind of connecting this collapse to the George Floyd protests. And, uh, they're also predicting a pretty robust May unemployment rate, just like they thought.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...experts looked ahead to a dismal May unemployment rate on the order of 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: It's fascinating, isn't it? Because you have, like, these celebrations in the streets, but then the market is just plummeting. It's really confounded a lot of investors, but the article we're looking at says this isn't actually a new phenomenon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's fascinating, isn't it? Because you have, like, these celebrations in the streets, but then the market is just plummeting. It's really confounded a lot of investors, but the article we're looking at says this isn't actually a new phenomenon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The disconnect between whats taking place on streets across America and the American stock market has stumped many investors but its not a new phenomenon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps slightly] Right, it's not. I mean, the market's collapse, it really shows just how interconnected all these societal events actually are. And if you look back at history, I mean, we've seen this before.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, it's not. I mean, the market's collapse, it really shows just how interconnected all these societal events actually are. And if you look back at history, I mean, we've seen this before.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The disconnect between whats taking place on streets across America and the American stock market has stumped many investors but its not a new phenomenon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, way back in '63, when President Kennedy was assassinated, the S&P, uh, plummeted nearly 20%. And then just two years later, for the Selma Civil Rights March, it crashed over 9%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, way back in one thousand, nine hundred sixty three, when President Kennedy was assassinated, the S and P, uh, plummeted nearly twenty percent. And then just two years later, for the Selma Civil Rights March, it crashed over nine percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1963, when President Kennedy was assassinated, the S&P added nearly 20%. In 1965, the year of the civil rights March in Selma, the S&P gained more than 9%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: And '67, the Vietnam protests, another 20% drop. Then '68, the year Dr. King was assassinated, um, it was down 8%. It's, like, a consistent pattern.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And one thousand, nine hundred sixty seven, the Vietnam protests, another twenty percent drop. Then one thousand, nine hundred sixty eight, the year Doctor King was assassinated, um, it was down eight percent. It's, like, a consistent pattern.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1967, the year of the Vietnam protests, the S&P soared more than 20%. In 1968, the year Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, the S&P gained 8%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Fast forward to more recent history, you know, 2003, after those huge protests erupted globally over the Iraq War, the S&P, uh, sunk a pretty eye-watering 26%. And then, of course, 2014, the start of Black Lives Matter with Ferguson, another 11% down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fast forward to more recent history, you know, two thousand three, after those huge protests erupted globally over the Iraq War, the S and P, uh, sunk a pretty eye-watering twenty six percent. And then, of course, twenty fourteen, the start of Black Lives Matter with Ferguson, another eleven percent down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2003, after protests erupted around the world over the Iraq War, the S&P jumped an eye watering 26%. In 2014, the year that sparked the beginning of the Black Lives Matter movement after the Ferguson protests, the S&P rose more than 11%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: And right now, just for the George Floyd protests alone, we're looking at about a 4.5% drop in the S&P 500 since May 26th. It really underscores this idea that markets are just inherently fragile during social and political upheaval.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And right now, just for the George Floyd protests alone, we're looking at about a four point five percent drop in the S and P five hundred since May twenty sixth. It really underscores this idea that markets are just inherently fragile during social and political upheaval.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Right now, the S&P 500 is up 4.5% since protests over the death of George Floyd began on May 26.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. I mean, take 1968, what some call "the year that shattered America." You had Vietnam escalating, MLK and Robert F. Kennedy assassinated. Amidst all that, the S&P still plummeted 8%. It's a clear link.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. I mean, take nineteen sixty eight, what some call the year that shattered America. You had Vietnam escalating, M L K and Robert F. Kennedy assassinated. Amidst all that, the S and P still plummeted eight percent. It's a clear link.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And after everything that happened, stocks in the S&P 500 still rose 8%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really paints a picture. And Jim Cramer from CNBC, he put it pretty succinctly this week. He said, "At the end of the day, the market has a conscience. Investors are terrified."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really paints a picture. And Jim Cramer from C N B C, he put it pretty succinctly this week. He said, At the end of the day, the market has a conscience. Investors are terrified.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of the day, the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money, CNBCs Jim Cramer said this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: And you can see why. I mean, company performance post-pandemic is looking pretty dire. Investors are really embracing what they call the "three Ps": Pandemic, Protests, and Politics. They're seeing this as an accelerated, uh, collapse in the economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And you can see why. I mean, company performance post-pandemic is looking pretty dire. Investors are really embracing what they call the three Ps: Pandemic, Protests, and Politics. They're seeing this as an accelerated, uh, collapse in the economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors are continuing to ignore the three Pspandemic, protests and politicsand are instead focused on what increasingly is being interpreted as a quicker and better than expected recovery in the economy...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: That's the sentiment, for sure. And the Fed has predicted major issues. But then, you know, it's interesting, the same Fed report also said that even though states are reopening, most businesses are actually *optimistic* about recovery. It's a mixed bag.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the sentiment, for sure. And the Fed has predicted major issues. But then, you know, it's interesting, the same Fed report also said that even though states are reopening, most businesses are actually optimistic about recovery. It's a mixed bag.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserves most recent report about the state of the economy, for instance, indicated that even though all 50 states are beginning to take their first steps toward reopening, most businesses are still pessimistic about the pace of economic recovery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is wild, right? And the IMF even predicted banks would see soaring profits through 2025. So there's this weird tension between the fear and some unexpected optimism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, right? And the I M F even predicted banks would see soaring profits through twenty twenty five. So there's this weird tension between the fear and some unexpected optimism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the IMF predicted that banks will suffer sharp declines in profits through 2025, and that substantial action will be needed to make up for earnings shortfalls caused by the coronavirus crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. So, what we really don't know, um, is when the market will actually recover. As Todd Lowenstein, chief equity strategist at HighMark Capital Management, put it, the market tends to price in a collapse well before the economic data actually bottoms out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. So, what we really don't know, um, is when the market will actually recover. As Todd Lowenstein, chief equity strategist at HighMark Capital Management, put it, the market tends to price in a collapse well before the economic data actually bottoms out.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Markets will price in a recovery well before the economic data bottoms, says Todd Lowenstein, chief equity strategist at HighMark Capital Management.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, essentially, what he's saying is, the market often lags the actual data. Which means, as much as we hope it's not true, the worst could actually still be yet to come. It's a lot to process.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, essentially, what he's saying is, the market often lags the actual data. Which means, as much as we hope it's not true, the worst could actually still be yet to come. It's a lot to process.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The market tends to be ahead of the actual data itself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really is. It just goes to show, you know, what happens on the streets and in society, it doesn't stay separate from the financial world. It's all connected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really is. It just goes to show, you know, what happens on the streets and in society, it doesn't stay separate from the financial world. It's all connected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The disconnect between whats taking place on streets across America and the American stock market has stumped many investors but its not a new phenomenon.
